headline: Amazon plans to launch AI content marketplace, The Information reports
summary: Amazon has signaled to publishing industry executives that it is planning ​to launch a marketplace where publishers ‌can sell their content to firms offering artificial intelligence products, ‌The Information reported on Monday.  Ahead of an Amazon Web Services conference on Tuesday, AWS has circulated slides that mention a content marketplace, the ⁠report said, citing ‌two people who spoke with Amazon about the project.

content.title: Amazon plans to launch AI content marketplace, The Information reports
content.summary: Amazon has signaled to publishing industry executives that it is planning ​to launch a marketplace where publishers ‌can sell their content to firms offering artificial intelligence products, ‌The Information reported on Monday. headline: Mexico Construction Equipment Industry Report 2026-2031 - Caterpillar, LiuGong, Komatsu, Liebherr, Volvo CE, John Deere, XCMG are the Front-runners by Offering a Diverse Set of Equipment
summary: The Mexico construction equipment market, valued at 32,188 units in 2025, is projected to grow at a CAGR of 3.08%, reaching 38,612 units by 2031. Earthmoving equipment, led by excavators, holds the largest market share, driven by the expanding mining sector. Material handling equipment demand is rising due to nearshoring and e-commerce, notably Amazon’s $6 billion investment in distribution centers. headline: TSMC Revenue Jumps 37% in January as AI Spending Marches On
summary: The contract chipmaker for Nvidia Corp. reported a 37% rise in January revenue to NT$401.3 billion ($12.7 billion), above the 30% revenue growth TSMC expects for the full year.  TSMC, which also produces chips for Apple Inc., has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of a surge in artificial intelligence-related investment, due to its role in manufacturing advanced AI accelerators.  Demand for data center chips in particular is spurring TSMC to earmark as much as $56 billion in capital spending this year, which would be up a quarter from 2025.

content.title: TSMC Revenue Jumps 37% in January as AI Spending Marches On
content.summary: The contract chipmaker for Nvidia Corp. reported a 37% rise in January revenue to NT$401.3 billion ($12.7 billion), above the 30% revenue growth TSMC expects for the full year.  TSMC, which also produces chips for Apple Inc., has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of a surge in artificial intelligence-related investment, due to its role in manufacturing advanced AI accelerators.  Demand for data center chips in particular is spurring TSMC to earmark as much as $56 billion in capital spending this year, which would be up a quarter from 2025.

headline: SenesTech Strengthens Direct-to-Consumer Commercial Strategy by Directly Managing Amazon Sales of Evolve™ Rat and Evolve™ Mouse
summary: SenesTech, Inc. (Nasdaq: SNES) today announced that it will begin directly managing sales of its Evolve™ Rat and Evolve™ Mouse products on Amazon. The change reflects the Company's continued focus on e-commerce as an important distribution channel and will be effective immediately.

The change reflects the Company's continued focus on e-commerce as an important distribution channel and will be effective immediately.

headline: Dutch Bros® CPG Products Expand to More Stores and Online
summary: Dutch Bros Inc. (NYSE: BROS) ("Dutch Bros"), one of the fastest-growing quick service beverage brands in the U.S., is bringing the flavors customers love to more places with its Dutch Bros at home assortment. After a gradual rollout, the lineup is now becoming available more broadly, giving customers even more ways to enjoy Dutch Bros.

(NYSE: BROS) ("Dutch Bros"), one of the fastest-growing quick service beverage brands in the U.S., is bringing the flavors customers love to more places with its Dutch Bros at home assortment. headline: Alphabet sells bonds worth $20 billion to fund AI spending
summary: Alphabet has sold bonds worth $20 billion in a seven-part offering, tapping the debt market to fund ​its surging spending on artificial intelligence infrastructure.  The disclosure on ‌Tuesday underscored Big Tech's growing appetite for credit, in a shift away from ‌years of relying on strong cash flows to fund investment in new technologies.  The pivot to bond market has raised investor concerns as payoffs have not kept pace with the mounting AI spending from U.S. ⁠tech giants, while businesses ‌adopting the technology have so far seen limited productivity gains.

content.title: Alphabet sells bonds worth $20 billion to fund AI spending
content.summary: Alphabet has sold bonds worth $20 billion in a seven-part offering, tapping the debt market to fund ​its surging spending on artificial intelligence infrastructure.  The disclosure on ‌Tuesday underscored Big Tech's growing appetite for credit, in a shift away from ‌years of relying on strong cash flows to fund investment in new technologies.  The pivot to bond market has raised investor concerns as payoffs have not kept pace with the mounting AI spending from U.S. ⁠tech giants, while businesses ‌adopting the technology have so far seen limited productivity gains.

thumbnail.caption: FILE PHOTO: Illustration shows Alphabet logo
